newsitem.title: MEXICO: Bidders line up for $1.2 bln Mexico Pemex project.
newsitem.headline: Bidders line up for $1.2 bln Mexico Pemex project.

text.p: Builders from around the world are preparing to bid for a $1.2 billion project to renovate and expand a key Mexican refinery, sources close to the process said late on Thursday.
The Cadereyta project calls for the construction of nine to 10 new plants, the renovation and expansion of three plants, the renovation of six plants and the construction of four sales terminals.
Companies have been applying to participate in the tender, with an expected winner decided by late August after recent changes to bidding requirements, sources said.
Firms that have so far applied for the bidding include:
--Italy's SNAM Progetti, controlled by ENI group
Other companies may also be submitting bids.
The sources said they expected affiliations between the companies, with many of the firms talking about possible joint bids. The project is expected to last about three years.
State oil and gas monopoly Petroleos Mexicanos (Pemex) has pitched the expansion as a means of reducing gasoline imports and making better use of a glut of heavy crude.
The northern refinery produced 177,400 barrels per day (bpd) of refined goods in 1995, according to Pemex data.
